HelpText: Forces the slicer to attempt to avoid having the perimeter line cross over existing perimeter lines. This can help with oozing or strings.
The shape of the physical print bed.
The X and Y values of the size of the print bed, in millimeters. For printers with a circular bed, these values are the diameters on the X and Y axes.
The temperature to which the bed will be set for the duration of the print. Set to 0 to disable.
The number of layers or the distance in millimeters to solid fill on the bottom surface(s) of the object. Add mm to the end of the number to specify distance in millimeters.
The layer(s) at which the print will pause, allowing for a change in filament. Leave blank to disable. To pause on multiple layers, separate the layer numbers with semicolons. For example: "16; 37".
The speed at which the layer cooling fan will run when bridging, expressed as a percentage of full power.
The speed at which bridging between walls will print.
The height of the printer's printable volume, in millimeters. Controls the height of the visual print area displayed in 3D View.
G-Code to run when a print is canceled.
Each individual part is printed to completion then the nozzle is lowered back to the bed and the next part is printed.
G-Code to run upon successful connection to a printer. This can be useful to set settings specific to a given printer.
Moves the nozzle up and off the part to allow cooling.
Turns on and off all cooling settings (all settings below this one).
Creates a raft under the printed part. Useful to prevent warping when printing ABS (and other warping-prone plastics) as it helps parts adhere to the bed.
The extra distance the raft will extend around the edge of the part.

The distance between the top of the raft and the bottom of the model. 0.6 mm is a good starting point for PLA and 0.4 mm is a good starting point for ABS. Lower values give a smoother surface, higher values make the print easier to remove.
The speed at which the cooling fan(s) will run during the printing of the raft, expressed as a percentage of full power.
The speed at which the layers of the raft (other than the first layer) will print. This can be set explicitly or as a percentage of the Infill speed.
The number of layers for which the layer cooling fan will be forced off at the start of the print.
G-Code to be run at the end of all automatic output (the very end of the G-Code commands).
DefaultValue: M104 S0 ; turn off temperature\nG28 X0 ; home X axis\nM84 ; disable motors

HelpText: The speed at which outside, external, or the otherwise visible perimeters will print.
Forces external perimeters to be printed first. By default, they will print last.
The number of extruders the printer has.
The offset of each nozzle relative to the first nozzle. Only useful for multiple extruder machines.
The z offset to apply to improve the first layer adhesion.
Used to specify if more than one extruder share a common heater cartridge.
Forces the printer to heat the nozzle before homing.
Detect perimeters that cross over themselves and combine them.
Detects sections of the model that would be too thin to print and expands them to make them printable.

All extrusions are multiplied by this value. Increasing it above 1 will increase the amount of filament being extruded (1.1 is a good max value); decreasing it will decrease the amount being extruded (.9 is a good minimum value).
Leave this as 0 to allow automatic calculation of extrusion width.
This will force the fan to remain on throughout the print. In general you should have this off and just enable auto cooling.

PresentationName: Enable Fan If Layer Print Time Is Below
HelpText: If a layer is estimated to take less than this to print, the fan will be turned on.
The price of one kilogram of filament. Used for estimating the cost of a print in the Layer View.
Material density. Only used for estimating mass in the Layer View.
The actual diameter of the filament used for printing.
The angle of the infill, measured from the X axis. Not used when bridging.
The amount of infill material to generate, expressed as a ratio or a percentage.
The geometric shape of the support structure for the inside of parts.
Detect gaps between perimeters that are too thin to fill with normal infill and attempt to fill them.
The temperature to set the bed to before printing the first layer. The printer will wait until this temperature has been reached before printing. Set to 0 to eliminate bed temperature commands.
A modifier of the width of the extrusion for the first layer of the print. A value greater than 100% can help with adhesion to the print bed.
The thickness of the first layer. A first layer taller than the default layer thickness can ensure good adhesion to the build plate.
The speed at which the nozzle will move when printing the initial layers. If expressed as a percentage the Infill speed is modified.
The number of layers to consider as the begining of the print. These will print at initial layer speed.
The speed at which the nozzle will move when recovering a failed print, for 1 layer.
When this is checked MatterControl will attempt to recover a print in the event of a failure, such as lost connection or lost power.
Checks before each print that the layer height is greater than the nozzle diameter (important for filament adhesion)
Indicates that the Z axis homes the hot end away from the bed (z-max homing)
The X and Y position of the hot end that minimizes the chance of colliding with the parts on the bed.
The temperature to which the nozzle will be heated before printing the first layer of a part. The printer will wait until this temperature has been reached before printing.
Use G0 for moves rather than G1.
The version of G-Code the printer's firmware communicates with. Some firmware use different G and M codes. Setting this ensures that the output G-Code will use the correct commands.
The version of G-Code the printer's firmware communicates with. Some firmware use different G and M codes. Setting this ensures that the output G-Code will use the correct commands.
The printer has a layer-cooling fan.
The printer has a z probe for measuring bed level.
The printer has a servo for lowering and rasing the z probe.
The printer has its own auto bed leveling probe and procedure which can be called using a G29 command during Start G-Code.
The printer has a heated bed.
Switch the settings interface to one intended for SLA printers.
This will only work on specific hardware. Do not use unless you are sure your printer controller supports this feature
The printer has the ability to control the power supply. Enable this function to show the ATX Power Control section on the Controls pane.
The printer has a SD card reader.
Shows a button at the right side of the Printer Connection Bar used to reset the USB connection to the printer. This can be used on printers that support it as an emergency stop.
Leave this as 0 to allow automatic calculation of extrusion width.
The amount the infill edge will push into the perimeter. Helps ensure the infill is connected to the edge.
The speed to move the laser when the layer height is 0.025mm. Speed will be ajusted linearly at other heights.
The speed to move the laser when the layer height is 0.1mm. Speed will be ajusted linearly at other heights.
The speed at which infill will print.
The geometric shape of the support structure for the inside of parts.
The print leveling algorithm to use.
ExtraSettings: 3 Point Plane,7 Point Disk,13 Point Disk,3x3 Mesh

HelpText: If set, these positions will be used when running the leveling solution. Leave empty for defaults. Data Format:'X1,Y1:...:Xn,Yn'
Specifies that the firmware has support for ros_0 endstop reporting on M119. TRIGGERED state defines filament has runout. If runout is detected the printers pause G-Code is run.
The starting height (z) of the print head before probing each print level position.
The distance the z probe is from the extruder in z. For manual probing, this is thickness of the paper (or other calibration device).
Enable this if your printer has hardware support for G30 (automatic bed probing) and you want to use it rather than manually measuring the probe positions.
The distance the z probe is from the extruder in x and y.
The number of times to sample each probe position (results will be averaged).
This is the angle that lowers or deploys the z probe.
This is the angle that raises or stows the z probe.
G-Code to be run after the change in Z height for the next layer.
The thickness of each layer of the print, except the first layer. A smaller number will create more layers and more vertical accuracy but also a slower print.
Sets the size of the outer solid surface (perimeter) for the entire print.
The maximum speed at which the layer cooling fan will run, expressed as a percentage of full power.
The minimum length of filament that must be extruded before a retraction can occur.
The minimum speed at which the layer cooling fan will run, expressed as a percentage of full power.
The minimum speed to which the printer will reduce to in order to attempt to make the layer print time long enough to satisfy the minimum layer time.

The minimum length of filament to use printing the skirt loops. Enough skirt loops will be drawn to use this amount of filament, overriding the value set in Loops if the value in Loops will produce a skirt shorter than this value.
These notes will be added as comments in the header of the output G-Code.
The diameter of the extruder's nozzle.
This will lower the temperature of the non-printing nozzle to help prevent oozing.
Experimental feature that attempts to improve overhangs using the fan and bridge settings.
Sets the models that will be added to the queue when a new printer is created.
Output only the first layer of the print. Especially useful for outputting gcode data for applications like engraving or cutting.
G-Code to run when the printer is paused.
Leave this as 0 to allow automatic calculation of extrusion width.
A modifier of the width of the extrusion when printing outside perimeters. Can be useful to fine-adjust actual print size when objects print larger or smaller than specified in the digital model.
The speed at which inside perimeters will print.
The distance that a perimeter will overlap itself when it completes its loop, expressed as a percentage of the Nozzle Diameter.
The number, or total width, of external shells to create. Add mm to the end of the number to specify width in millimeters.
You can include additional programs to process the G-Code after slicer is finished. The complete path of the program to run should be included here.
The position (X and Y coordinates) of the center of the print bed, in millimeters. Normally this is 1/2 the bed size for Cartesian printers and 0, 0 for Delta printers.
Number of layers to print before printing any parts.
Start each new layer from a different vertex to reduce seams.
G-Code to be run when the print resumes after a pause.
The minimum distance of a non-print move which will trigger a retraction.
Turn retractions on and off.
The distance filament will reverse before each qualifying non-print move
When using multiple extruders, the distance filament will reverse before changing to a different extruder.
Force a retraction when moving between islands (distinct parts on the layer).
The distance the nozzle will lift after each retraction.
Length of extra filament to extrude after a complete tool change (in addition to the re-extrusion of the tool change retraction distance).
Length of filament to extrude after a complete retraction (in addition to the re-extrusion of the Length on Move distance).
The time over which to increase the Extra Length On Restart to its maximum value. Below this time only a portion of the extra length will be applied. Leave 0 to apply the entire amount all the time.
The speed at which filament will retract and re-extrude.
Try to connect mesh edges when the actual mesh data is not all the way connected.
Sometime a mesh will not have closed a perimeter. When this is checked these non-closed perimeters while be closed.
The minimum feature size to consider from the model. Leave at 0 to use all the model detail.
The distance from the model at which the first skirt loop is drawn. Make this 0 to create an anchor for the part to the bed, also known as a brim.
The number of layers to draw the skirt.
The number of loops to draw around all the parts on the bed before starting on the parts. Used mostly to prime the nozzle so the flow is even when the actual print begins.
The number of loops to draw around parts. Used to provide additional bed adhesion

PresentationName: Slow Down If Layer Print Time Is Below
HelpText: The minimum amount of time a layer must take to print. If a layer will take less than this amount of time, the movement speed is reduced so the layer print time will match this value, down to the minimum print speed at the slowest.
Used for small perimeters (usually holes). This can be set explicitly or as a percentage of the Perimeters' speed.
The pattern used on the bottom and top layers of the print.
Leave this as 0 to allow automatic calculation of extrusion width.
The speed to print infill when completely solid. This can be set explicitly or as a percentage of the Infill speed.
Forces the print to have only one extrusion and gradually increase the Z height during the print. Only one part will print at a time with this feature.
The number of degrees Centigrade to lower the temperature of a nozzle while it is not active.

G-Code to be run immediately following the temperature setting commands. Including commands to set temperature in this section will cause them not be generated outside of this section. Will accept Custom G-Code variables.
DefaultValue: G28 ; home all axes\nG1 Z5 F5000 ; lift nozzle

HelpText: This is a set of regular expressions to apply to lines prior to sending to a printer. They will be applied in the order listed before sending. To return more than one instruction separate them with comma.
This is a set of regular expressions to apply to lines after they are received from the printer. They will be applied in order to each line received.
Make sure the first point on a perimeter is a concave point.
Make sure the first point on a perimeter is not an overhang.
The distance between the top of the support and the bottom of the model. A good value depends on the type of material. For ABS and PLA a value between 0.4 and 0.6 works well, respectively.
The starting angle of the supports.
The percent of the extrusion width that can be overlapped and still generate.
The angle at which the support material lines will be drawn.
Generates support material starting on top of internal surfaces. If unchecked support will only generate starting on the bed.
Generates an outline around the support material to improve strength and hold up interface layers.
Generate support material everywhere not touching the bed for n layers, regardless of angle.
The index of the extruder to use for printing support material. Applicable only when Extruder Count is set to a value more than 1.
The index of the extruder to use to print the raft. Set to 0 to use the support extruder index.
A modifier of the width of the extrusion when printing support material. Set to 0 for automatic calculation.
The index of the extruder to use for support material interface layer(s).
The number of layers or the distance to print solid material between the supports and the part. Add mm to the end of the number to specify distance.
The space between lines of the interface layers (0 is solid).
The pattern to draw for the generation of support material.
The distance between support material lines.
The speed at which support material structures will print.
The minimum angle of overhang for which support material will be created. The angle perpendicular to the bed = 0; parallel with the bed = 90.
The distance the support material will be from the object in the X and Y directions.
The distance the support material will be from the object in the z direction.
The number of layers, or the distance, to skip between the support (including interface layers) and the model. Add mm to the end of the number to specify distance.
Generates support material under areas of the part which may be too steep to support themselves.
The pattern to draw for the generation of support material.
The target temperature the extruder will attempt to reach during the print.
The temperature at which the extruder will wipe the nozzle, as specified by Custom G-Code.
The temperature to which the bed will heat (or cool) in order to remove the part, as specified in Custom G-Code.
Detect when walls are too close together and need to be extruded as just one wall.
The number of CPU cores to use while doing slicing. Increasing this can slow down your machine.
G-Code to be run after every tool change.
G-Code to be run before every tool change.
Leave this as 0 to allow automatic calculation of extrusion width.
The speed at which the top solid layers will print. Can be set explicitly or as a percentage of the Infill speed.
The number of layers, or the distance in millimeters, to solid fill on the top surface(s) of the object. Add mm to the end of the number to specify distance in millimeters.
The speed at which the nozzle will move when not extruding material.
Request the firmware to do retractions rather than specify the extruder movements directly.
Normally you will want to use absolute e distances. Only check this if you know your printer needs relative e distances.
The serial port communication speed of the printers firmware.
This is the name of your printer that will be displayed in the choose printer menu.
If set, the printer will automatically attempt to connect when selected.
The serial port to use while connecting to this printer.
This is to help reduce vibrations during printing. If your printer has a resonance frequency that is causing trouble you can set this to try and reduce printing at that frequency.
The extruder will wipe the nozzle over the last up to 10 mm of tool path after retracting.
Creates a perimeter around the part on which to wipe the other nozzle when printing using dual extrusion. Set to 0 to disable.
The length and width of a tower created at the back left of the print used for wiping the next nozzle when changing between multiple extruders. Set to 0 to disable.
Sets MatterControl to attempt to connect to a printer over the network. (You must disconnect and reconnect for this to take effect)
Sets MatterControl to use s3g communication method. (You must disconnect and reconnect for this to take effect)
IP Address of printer/printer controller
Port number to be used with IP Address to connect to printer over the network
The distance to move the nozzle along the Z axis to ensure that it is the correct distance from the print bed. A positive number will raise the nozzle, and a negative number will lower it.
Controls the speed of printer moves
Controls the amount of extrusion
Axis movement speeds
